Eliza Dushku |publisher=YouTube (via Freddie Wong) |date=May 13, 2011 |accessdate=May 13, 2011}} In August of the same year, Dushku visited [[Albania]] with a crew from the [[Travel Channel]] and [[Lonely Planet]] to film a documentary entitled ''[[Dear Albania]]'', promoting tourism in her father's country of origin.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fFTTx8P0Wsw |title=Dear Albania by Eliza Dushku |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=October 15, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/eliza-dushku/albania-travel-_b_946341.html |title=Why You Must Visit Albania |work=Huffington Post|date=September 2, 2011 |accessdate=March 11, 2012 |first=Eliza |last=Dushku}}{{cite web |url=http://news.bostonherald.com/track/star_tracks/view/2011_0808inside_track_headline_2/srvc=home&position=also |title=Eliza Dushku in Albania - BostonHerald.com |publisher=[[Boston Herald]] |date=August 8, 2011 |accessdate=October 15, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120912195515/http://news.bostonherald.com/track/star_tracks/view/2011_0808inside_track_headline_2/srvc%3Dhome%26position%3Dalso |archivedate=September 12, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.koha.net/index.php?page=1,5,65224 |title=Eliza Dushku në Tiranë, promovon vlerat turistike të Shqipërisë |work=Koha.net|date=August 6, 2011 |accessdate=August 7, 2011}} Dushku had a lead role in an online animated "motion comic" series, titled ''Torchwood: Web of Lies'', based on the BBC series ''[[Torchwood: Miracle Day]]''.{{cite news|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/06/02/eliza-dushku-torchwood/|title=Eliza Dushku to star in 'Torchwood' online animated series|last=Hibberd|first=James|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=June 2, 2011|accessdate=June 3, 2011}} In June 2012, Dushku starred with [[Katie Cassidy]], [[Gina Gershon]] and [[Michelle Trachtenberg]] in ''[[The Scribbler (film)|The Scribbler]]'' directed by John Suits and produced by [[Gabriel Cowan]].{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/05/the-scribbler-starts-production-with-katie-cassidy-starring/ |title='The Scribbler' Starts Production With Katie Cassidy Starring |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=July 1, 2013}} In 2013, she was cast as [[Patricia Holm]] in a pilot film for a proposed TV revival series of ''[[Simon Templar|The Saint]]'', but the series was not commissioned. In July 2017 the pilot was released on digital HD/VOD.{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwtv/article/All-New-Reboot-of-THE-SAINT-Arrives-on-Digital-HDVOD-on-Today-20170710|title=All-New Reboot of THE SAINT Arrives on Digital HD/VOD on Today|publisher=|accessdate=16 July 2017}} From 2013 to 2015, Dushku voiced the role of [[She-Hulk]] in the [[Disney XD]] animated series ''[[Hulk and the Agents of S.M.A.S.H.]]''. In 2016, she had a recurring role in the fourth and final season of the [[Cinemax]] TV series ''[[Banshee (TV series)|Banshee]]''. In 2017, she had a recurring guest role in the last three episodes of the first season of the [[CBS]] drama series ''[[Bull (2016 TV series)|Bull]]'' with the option of becoming a series regular in season two.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/eliza-dushku-bull-cbs-cast-1202014922/|title=Eliza Dushku Joins CBS’ ‘Bull’ With Option to Become Series Regular in Season 2|first=Elizabeth|last=Wagmeister|date=March 23, 2017|publisher=}} Additionally, her production company in association with IM Global Television was reported to be developing [[Glen Cook]]'s ''[[The Black Company]]'' series of books for a television series with Dushku starring as The Lady.{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2017/04/eliza-dushku-star-the-black-company-series-adaptation-david-goyer-im-global-1202076367/|title=Eliza Dushku To Star In ‘The Black Company’ Series Adaptation In Works By IM Global & David Goyer|date=24 April 2017|publisher=|accessdate=16 July 2017}} ==Personal life== [[File:Eliza Dushku Fan Expo 2011, 2.jpg|thumb|upright|Dushku at [[Fan Expo Canada]] in [[Toronto]], 2011]] Dushku was raised as a [[Mormon]], as a member of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/home3/58379865-200/dushku-curtis-judy-mormon.html.csp|title=Eliza Dushku of 'Buffy,' 'Dollhouse' shares Comic Con stage with mom|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|accessdate=October 27, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141016121246/http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/home3/58379865-200/dushku-curtis-judy-mormon.html.csp|archivedate=October 16, 2014|df=mdy-all}} Dushku visited her father's family in [[Albania]] in 2006 after receiving an invitation from [[Prime Minister of Albania|Albanian Prime Minister]] [[Sali Berisha]]. She visited [[Kosovo]] and received an [[Double-headed eagle|Albanian Eagle]] tattoo on the back of her neck.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/celebrity/articles/2006/06/08/dushku_wears_her_heritage_proudly/|title=Dushku Wears Her Heritage Proudly|last=Beggy|first=Carol|author2=Mark Shanahan|date=June 8, 2006|work=The Boston Globe |page=E9|accessdate=July 13, 2008}}{{cite news|title=Dushku finds Tru Calling in Albania homeland|date=June 8, 2006|publisher=[[The Boston Herald]]|page=019}} While on her second visit to Albania in 2011, she applied for Albanian citizenship and obtained the [[Albanian passport]] and [[Albanian Identity Card|ID Card]]. She became an honorary citizen of [[Tirana]],{{cite web|url=http://www.tirana.gov.al/?cid=1,62,4289|title=Bashkia e Tiranës - Bashkia e Tiranës|publisher=Tirana.gov.al|accessdate=October 15, 2012}} and was given the honorary title of Tirana Ambassador of Culture and Tourism in the World by Tirana mayor [[Lulzim Basha]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vJeWvr6g8wE|title=Eliza Dushku me Bashen ambasadore e Tiranes|publisher=YouTube (via kushtha)|date=August 7, 2011|accessdate=August 7, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.botasot.info/def.php?gjuha=0&category=6&id=131431|title=Basha: Eliza Dushku, ambasadore nderi e Tiranës në botë|work=Botasot|date=August 7, 2011|accessdate=August 7, 2011}}{{Dead link|date=July 2013}} Additionally, she was given honorary citizen status in her father's home town of [[Korçë]], [[Albania]]. She is the founder and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Boston Diva Productions]]{{cite web|title=Boston Diva Productions |url=https://www.imdb.com/company/co0263223|accessdate=December 3, 2015}} and serves on the board of directors of the THRIVEGulu organization (The Trauma Healing and Reflection Center in Gulu), an organization dedicated to helping the survivors of war (including former child soldiers) in [[Districts of Uganda|Northern Uganda]]. As a role model to campus leaders for her activism, Dushku was invited by the Millennium Campus Network (MCN) as a national keynote speaker and honored as a Global Generation Award winner alongside U.S. Secretary of State [[John Kerry]] at MCN events in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/celebrity/articles/2011/09/20/dushku_honored_at_global_generation_awards/ |title=Dushku honored at Global Generation Awards - The Boston Globe |publisher=Boston.com |date=September 20, 2011 |accessdate=July 1, 2013}} [[File:WW St Louis 2014 - Eliza Dushku (13768586685).jpg|thumb|upright|left|Dushku at Wizard World on April 6, 2014]] Dushku has stated that she has [[attention deficit hyperactivity disorder]] (ADHD).{{cite web|title=CELEBRATION: Love & Bliss FLOW WITH ME..! 4/14/14|url=http://www.elizapatriciadushku.com/news/celebration-love-bliss-flow-with-me-4-14-14|website=Eliza Dushku's official website|date= |accessdate=October 15, 2016}} She began dating former [[Los Angeles Lakers]] basketball player [[Rick Fox]] in October 2009, and in August 2010 the couple confirmed that they were living together.{{cite web|url=http://www.americansuperstarmag.com/news/eliza-dushku-confirms-shes-dating-rick-fox |title=Eliza Dushku Confirms She's Dating Rick Fox |publisher=Americansuperstarmag.com |date=October 15, 2009 |accessdate=February 27, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20412945,00.html|title=Eliza Dushku and Rick Fox Love Living Together|first=Dahvi|last=Shira|date=August 13, 2010|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=February 27, 2011}} It was announced on June 24, 2014, that the pair had split.{{cite news|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/553846/eliza-dushku-and-rick-fox-break-up|title=Eliza Dushku and Rick Fox Break Up|last=Johnson|first=Zach|work=[[E!|E! Online]]|date=June 24, 2014|accessdate=June 24, 2014}} Dushku announced in December 2011, that she had decided to switch to a [[vegan]] diet after watching the documentary ''[[Forks over Knives]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-3614/Eliza-Dushku-Goes-Vegan.html|title= Eliza Dushku Goes Vegan|publisher=MindBodyGreen|date=December 7, 2011|accessdate=April 25, 2012}} In December 2014 she said on her [[Twitter]] page she was no longer a vegetarian.{{cite web|last1=Dushku|first1=Eliza|title=Eliza no longer vegetarian|url=https://twitter.com/elizadushku/status/542455198682071041|website=[[Twitter]]|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Dushku, who had originally intended to attend college in [[Boston]] before her big break on ''Buffy'' altered those plans, announced in March 2014 at the [[Emerald City Comicon]] that she would be attending college later that year. Dushku previously resided in [[Laurel Canyon, Los Angeles]], California.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/travel/getaways/us/california/gallery/show_us_los_angeles?pg=7|title=Eliza Dushku shows us L.A.|last=Maeda|first=Wendy|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=August 28, 2007|accessdate=June 3, 2011}} On June 22, 2014, ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' reported that Dushku had left Los Angeles, moved back to Boston, and was planning to attend college.{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/lifestyle/names/2014/06/21/eliza-dushku-separated-from-rick-fox-moves-back-home|title=Eliza Dushku leaves LA and moves back home|publisher=The Boston Globe|date=June 22, 2014|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} She is currently a student at [[Suffolk University]], studying [[sociology]].{{cite web|url=http://sparechangenews.net/2016/02/dear-albania-eliza-dushku-discusses-immigration-bernie-sanders-and-homelessness/|title=Dear Albania: Eliza Dushku discusses Immigration, Bernie Sanders, and Homelessness|last=Greenough|first=Jason|publisher=Spare Change News|date=February 25, 2016|accessdate=April 3, 2016}} Dushku is politically active and campaigned for [[Bernie Sanders]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|U.S. presidential election of 2016]]. On March 7, 2017, Dushku attended a Youth Summit on Opioid Awareness, where she revealed that she was a recovering alcoholic and drug addict, having begun drinking and abusing drugs at the age of 14. She said her addictions were at one point so serious that her brother forbade her from being left alone with her niece, his daughter Sofia. She said that at the current time, she was eight-and-a-half years sober.{{citation|last1=WMUR-TV|title=Actress Eliza Dushku addresses students at NH Youth Summit on Opioid Awareness|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=kE_YylDaX5g|date=7 March 2017|via=YouTube}} In June 2017, she became engaged to [[Peter Palandjian]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-4616786/Eliza-Dushku-flashes-engagement-ring-Awesome-Con.html|title=Eliza Dushku flashes her engagement ring just days after saying yes|work=Mail Online|access-date=2017-06-20}} and they wed on August 18, 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/tv/celebrity/eliza-dushku-marries-peter-palandjian-in-boston-photos/ar-BBNpMpE|title=Eliza Dushku marries Peter Palandjian in Boston: Photos|website=www.msn.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-17}} === Sexual abuse accusation === On January 13, 2018, Dushku published, on Facebook, an account of her sexual molestation at the hand of stunt coordinator Joel Kramer when she was 12 and working on ''[[True Lies]]''. According to Dushku, Kramer groomed her with flattery and special attention until, one day, he lured her to his Miami hotel room, took off all his clothes, lay Dushku on the bed, and rubbed himself against her (dressed) until he ejaculated. Kramer was 36 at the time of the alleged encounter. Dushku claims that soon after, an adult friend of Dushku confronted Kramer on set, and that the same day, Dushku was injured during a stunt and several of her ribs were broken; She says Kramer was responsible for her safety.Facebook post on Eliza Dushku's page, January 13, 2018, retrieved January 13, 2018. https://www.facebook.com/OfficialElizaDushku/posts/1769957739689557 Kramer has denied the accusation of sexual misconduct.{{cite news|last1=Mumford|first1=Gwilym|title=Eliza Dushku claims True Lies crew member sexually assaulted her aged 12|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/jan/15/eliza-dushku-accuses-true-lies-crew-member-of-sexually-assaulting-her-aged-12|accessdate=16 January 2018|work=The Guardian|date=15 January 2018}} ==Awards and nominations== Her performance in ''[[Tru Calling]]'' garnered her two nominations in 2004: for a [[Teen Choice Awards|Teen Choice Award]] as Choice Breakout Star – Female, and for a [[Saturn Award]] as Best Actress in a Television Series. {{Infobox Officeholder |name=Genrikh Grigoryevich Yagoda |image=1936 genrich grigorijewitsch jagoda.jpg |caption=Genrikh Grigoryevich Yagoda at the podium in 1936 |order = People's Commissar for Internal Affairs ([[NKVD]]) | term_start = 10 July 1934 | term_end = 26 September 1936 | predecessor = [[Vyacheslav Menzhinsky]] | successor = [[Nikolai Yezhov]] |birth_name=Yenokh Gershevich Iyeguda | birth_date = 7 November 1891 | birth_place = [[Rybinsk]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1938|3|15|1891|11|7}} | death_place = [[Moscow]], [[Russian SFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | nationality = [[Soviet people|Soviet]] | Ethnically = Jewish | party = [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] | spouse =Ida Leonidovna Averbach | children = }} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} '''Genrikh Grigoryevich Yagoda''' (7 November 1891 – 15 March 1938), born '''Yenokh Gershevich Iyeguda''' was a [[secret police]] official who served as director of the [[NKVD]], the [[Soviet Union]]'s security and intelligence agency, from 1934 to 1936. Appointed by [[Joseph Stalin]], Yagoda supervised the arrest, [[Moscow Show Trial|show trial]], and execution of the [[Old Bolshevik]]s [[Lev Kamenev]] and [[Grigory Zinoviev]], climactic events of the [[Great Purge]]. Yagoda supervised the construction of the [[White Sea–Baltic Canal]] with [[Naftaly Frenkel]], using penal labor from the [[GULAG]] system, during which many laborers died. Like many Soviet NKVD officers who conducted political repression, Yagoda himself became ultimately a victim of the Purge. He was demoted from the directorship of the NKVD in favor of [[Nikolai Yezhov]] in 1936 and arrested in 1937. Charged with the crimes of [[wrecking (Soviet crime)|wrecking]], espionage, [[Trotskyism]] and conspiracy, Yagoda was a defendant at the [[Case of the Anti-Soviet "Bloc of Rights and Trotskyites"|Trial of the Twenty-One]], the last of the major Soviet show trials of the 1930s. Following his confession at the trial, Yagoda was found guilty and shot. ==Early life== [[File:1912 genrich jagoda kartei orchrana.jpg|thumb|left|Genrikh Grigoryevich Yagoda on police information card from 1912]] Yagoda was born in [[Rybinsk]] into a [[Jewish]] family. The son of a jeweller, trained as a statistician, who worked as a chemist's assistant,{{cite book|last1=Montefiore|first1=Simon Sebag|title=Stalin, The Court of the Red Tsar|date=2004|publisher=Phoenix|location=London|isbn=0 75381 766 7|page=98}} he claimed that he was an active revolutionary from the age of 14, when he worked as a compositor on an underground printing press in [[Nizhni-Novgorod]], and that at the age of 15 he was a member of a fighting squad in the Sormovo district of Nizhni-Novgorod, during the violent suppression of the [[1905 revolution]]. One of his brothers was killed during the fighting in Sormovo; the other was shot for taking part in a mutiny in a regiment during the war with Germany. He said he joined the Bolsheviks in Nizhni-Novgorod at the age of 16 or 17, and was arrested and sent into exile in 1911.{{cite book|title=The Case of the Anti Soviet Bloc of Rights and Trotskyites, Verbatim Report|date=1938|publisher=People's Commissariat of Justice of the U.S.S.R.|location=Moscow|page=784|last1=See Yagoda's last plea at his trial in}} Before his arrest, he married Ida Averbakh, one of whose uncles, Yakov Sverdlov, was a prominent Bolshevik, and another, [[Zinovy Peshkov]], was the adopted son of the writer Maxim Gorky. In 1913, he moved to St Petersburg to work at the Putilov steel works. After the outbreak of war, he joined the army, and was wounded in action.{{cite book|last1=Бажанов|first1=Борис|last2=Кривицкий|first2=Вальтер|last3=Орлов|first3=Александр|title=Ягода. Смерть главного чекиста (сборник)|date=2014|isbn=978-5-457-26136-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6eNgAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT225&dq=%22%D0%9D%D0%B0+%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%BC+%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5+%D0%AF%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0+%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BA%D0%BD%D1%83%D0%BB+%D0%BA+%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B8+%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%BE+%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC+1917+%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjWwMif2MPJAhWEwiYKHYUvAR0Q6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=%22%D0%9D%D0%B0%20%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%BC%20%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%20%D0%AF%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%20%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BA%D0%BD%D1%83%D0%BB%20%D0%BA%20%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B8%20%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%BE%20%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%201917%20%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%22&f=false}} [[File:1915-genrich yagoda.jpg|thumb|280px|Yagoda in 1915]] There is another version of his early career, told in the memoirs of the former NKVD officer [[Aleksandr Mikhailovich Orlov|Aleksandr M. Orlov]], who alleged that Yagoda invented his early revolutionary career and did not join the Bolsheviks until 1917, and that his deputy [[Mikhail Trilisser]] was dismissed from the service for trying to expose the lie.{{Cite book|title=The Secret History of Stalin's Crimes|last=Orlov|first=Alexander|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}} It can be assumed that this was gossip put around by Yagoda's successors after his fall from power. == Political career == After the [[October Revolution]] of 1917, Yagoda rose rapidly through the ranks of the ''[[Cheka]]'' (the predecessor of the OGPU and [[NKVD]]) to become the second deputy of [[Felix Dzerzhinsky]], the head of the Cheka, in September 1923. After Dzerzhinsky's appointment as chairman of the Supreme Council of National Economy in January 1924, Yagoda became the real manager of the [[Gosudarstvennoye Politicheskoye Upravlenie|State Political Directorate]] (OGPU), as the deputy chairman [[Vyacheslav Menzhinsky]] had little authority because of his serious illness. In 1924, he joined the USSR's head of government, [[Alexei Rykov]] on a ship tour of the Volga. An American journalist who was allowed to join them on the trip described Yagoda as "a spare, slightly-tanned, trim looking, youngish officer" adding that it was "difficult to associate terror with the affable and modest person".{{Cite book|title=I Dreamt Revolution|last=Reswick|first=William|publisher=Henry Regnery Company|year=1952|isbn=|location=Chicago|pages=85}} By contrast, the chemist [[Vladimir Ipatieff]] met Yagoda briefly in Moscow in 1918 and thought that "it was unusual for a young men in his early twenties to be so unpleasant. I felt then that it would be unlucky for me or anyone else ever to fall into his hands." When he saw him again in 1927, "his appearance had changed considerably: he had grown fatter and looked much older and very dignified and important."{{Cite book|title=The Life of a Chemist: Memoirs of Vladimir Ipatieff|last=Ipatieff|first=Vladimir|publisher=Stanford University Press|year=1946|isbn=|location=Stanford, Ca|pages=}} [[File:Genrikh Yagoda and Ida Averbakh 1922.jpg|thumb|Genrikh Yagoda and his wife Ida Averbakh, 30 September 1922. Ida was executed in 1938]] [[File:1924 yagoda menshinsky dsershinsky.jpg|thumb|left|380px| Yagoda, [[Vyacheslav Menzhinsky|Menzhinsky]], [[Felix Dzerzhinsky|Dzerzhinsky]], 1920]] Though Yagoda appears to have known [[Joseph Stalin]] since 1918, when they were both stationed in [[Tsaritsyn]] during the civil war, "he was never Stalin's man"{{Cite book|title=Stalin, The Court of the Red Tsar|last=Montefiore|first=Simon Sebag|publisher=Phoenix|year=2004|isbn=0 75381 766 7|location=London|pages=98}} When Stalin ordered that the Soviet Union's entire rural population were to be forced onto collective farms, Yagoda is reputed to have sympathised with Bukharin and Rykov, his opponents on the right of the communist party. [[Nikolai Bukharin]] claimed in a leaked private conversation in July 1928 that "Yagoda and Trilisser are with us", but once it became apparent that the right was losing the power struggle, Yagoda switched allegiance. In the contemptuous opinion of Bukharin's widow, Anna Larina, Yagoda "traded his personal views for the sake of his career" and degenerated into a "criminal" and a "miserable coward".{{Cite book|title=This I Cannot Forget|last=Larina|first=Anna|publisher=Pandora|year=1993|isbn=0 04 440887 0|location=London|pages=100–101}} [[File:1922 exit visa hand signed by Genrikh Yagoda..jpg|thumb|1922 exit visa hand signed by Genrikh Yagoda in Moscow.]] Yagoda continued to be effective head of the OGPU until July 1931, when the little known Old Bolshevik [[Ivan Akulov]] was appointed First Deputy Chairman, and Yagoda was demoted to the post of Second Deputy. Akulov was dismissed and Yagoda reinstated in October 1932, After Yagoda's fall, one of his former colleagues confessed: "We met Akulov with violent hostility...the entire party organisation in the OGPU was devoted to sabotaging Akulov."{{Cite book|title=I Was Stalin's Agent|last=Krivitsly|first=W.G.|publisher=The Right Book Club|year=1940|isbn=|location=London|pages=170}} Stalin must have agreed to his reinstatement with ill grace, because four years later he accused the OGPU/NKVD of being "four years behind" in rooting out the supposed Trotskyite anti-Soviet conspiracy, although Yagoda had been complicit in the execution of one of Trotsky's sympathisers, [[Yakov Blumkin]], and in sending others to the [[GULAG]], the system of forced labour created under his supervision. As deputy head of the OGPU, Yagoda organized the building of the [[White Sea–Baltic Canal]] using [[forced labor]] at breakneck speed between 1931 and 1933 at the cost of huge casualties.[http://www.gulag.eu/GULAG/Storm.html ''Gulag, The Storm projects - The White Sea Canal''], ''Gulag.eu''. Retrieved 28 August 2011. For his contribution to the canal's construction he was later awarded the [[Order of Lenin]].[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,745910,00.html "Russia: Canal Heroes"], ''[[Time Magazine]]''; 14 August 1933. Retrieved 28 August 2011. The construction of the [[Moscow-Volga Canal]] was started under his watch, but only completed after his fall by his successor [[Nikolai Yezhov]].[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,758021,00.html "Russia: Stalin's Mercy"]; ''Time Magazine''; 26 July 1937. Retrieved on 28 August 2011. Yagoda supervised the deportations, confiscations, mass arrests and executions that accompanied the forced collectivisation, and was one of the people responsible for the [[Holodomor]], which resulted in the deaths of at least 7.5 million people.{{cite web|url=http://www.ukemonde.com/genocide/margolisholocaust.html|title=Seven million died in the 'forgotten' holocaust - Eric Margolis|website=www.ukemonde.com|accessdate=1 April 2018}}Agnieszka Bieńczyk-Missala, Sławomir Dębski (2010). Rafał Lemkin - ''Holodomor: the Ukrainian holocaust''. Polski Instytut Spraw Miedzynarodowyc. p. 225 In March 1934, he was rewarded by being made a member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. Yagoda had founded [[Poison laboratory of the Soviet secret services|a secret poison laboratory of OGPU]] that was at disposal of Stalin. One of the victims became his own NKVD boss, [[Vyacheslav Menzhinsky]]. He was slowly poisoned during two weeks by two assistants of Yagoda''The Secret File of Joseph Stalin: A Hidden Life'' by Roman Brackman, Routledge, 2004, p.204-205 Menzhinsky's death was followed one day later by death of Max Peshkov, the son of [[Maxim Gorky]], the doyen of Soviet literature. Yagoda had been cultivating Gorky as a potentially useful contact since 1928, and employed Gorky's secretary, Pyotr Kryuchkov, as a spy. "Whenever Gorky met Stalin or other members of the [[Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Politburo]], Yagoda would visit Kryuchkov's flat afterward, demanding a full account of what had been said. He took to visiting public baths with Kryuchkov. One day in 1932, Yagoda handed his valuable spy $4,000 to buy a car."{{Cite book|title=Fear and the Muse Kept Watch, The Russian Masters - from Akhmatov and Pasternak to Shostakovich and Eisenstein - Under Stalin|last=McSmith|first=Andy|publisher=The New Press|year=2015|isbn=978-1-59558-056-6|location=New York|pages=91|via=}} He had developed an obsession with Max Peshkov's wife, Timoshka, and visited her daily when she was newly widowed, though her mother denied that they were ever lovers.{{Cite book|title=Fear and the Muse Kept Watch|last=McSmith|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=92|via=}} According to [[Arkady Vaksberg]] and other researchers, Yagoda poisoned [[Maksim Gorky]] and his son on the orders from Joseph Stalin.[[Arkady Vaksberg]], ''The Murder of Maxim Gorky: A Secret Execution'', 2006, Enigma Books, {{ISBN|1929631626}} ===NKVD Chief=== [[File:1930 jagoda.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Yagoda at his desk in 1930]] [[File:Yagoda kanal Moskva Volga.jpg|thumb|280px|right|Yagoda (middle) inspecting the construction of the Moscow-Volga canal. Behind him is [[Nikita Khrushchev]].]] On 10 July 1934, two months after Menzhinsky's death, Joseph Stalin appointed Yagoda [[People's Commissar]] for Internal Affairs, a position that included the oversight of both the regular and the secret police, the [[NKVD]]. Yagoda worked closely with [[Andrei Vyshinsky]] in organizing the first [[Moscow Trials|Moscow Show Trial]], which resulted in the prosecution and subsequent execution of former Soviet politicians Grigory Zinoviev and Lev Kamenev in August 1936 as part of Stalin's [[Great Purge]]. The [[Red Army]] high command was not spared and its ranks were thinned by Yagoda, as a precursor to the later and more extensive [[Case of Trotskyist Anti-Soviet Military Organization|purge in the Russian military]]. More than a quarter of a million people were arrested during the 1934–1935 period; the GULAG system was vastly expanded under his stewardship, and penal labor became a major developmental resource in the Soviet economy. Stalin became increasingly disillusioned with Yagoda's performance. In the middle of 1936, Stalin received a report from Yagoda detailing the unfavorable public reaction abroad to the show trials and the growing sympathy among the Soviet population for the executed defendants. The report enraged Stalin, interpreting it as Yagoda's advice to stop the show trials and in particular to abandon the planned purge of [[Mikhail Tukhachevsky]], [[Marshal of the Soviet Union]] and the former commander in chief of the Red Army. Stalin was already unhappy with Yagoda's services, mostly due to the mismanagement of Kirov's assassination and his failure to fabricate "proofs" of ties between Kamenev and Zinoviev and the [[Okhrana]] (the tsarist security organization).Brackman, Roman., [https://books.google.com/books?id=nA7YzQMzO9YC&pg=PA231 ''The Secret File of Joseph Stalin: A Hidden Life''], London: Frank Cass Publishers (2001), p. 231 As one Soviet official put it, "The Boss forgets nothing."Barmine, Alexander, ''One Who Survived'', New York: G.P. Putnam (1945), pp. 295-296 On 25 September 1936, Stalin sent a telegram (co-signed by [[Andrei Zhdanov]]) to the members of the [[Politburo of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Politburo]]. The telegram read:
"We consider it absolutely necessary and urgent that Comrade Yezhov be appointed to head the People's Commissariat of Internal Affairs. ''Yagoda has obviously proved unequal to the task of exposing the Trotskyite-Zinovievite bloc.'' The [[State Political Directorate|GPU]] was four years late in this matter. All party heads and the most of the NKVD agents in the region are talking about this."Medvedev, Roy. ''Let History Judge'', New York (1971), p. 174
A day later, he was replaced by Yezhov, who managed the main purges during 1937–1938. Yagoda was demoted to the post of [[People's Commissariat for Post and Telegraph|People's Commissar for Post and Telegraph]]. ===Arrest, trial, and execution=== In March 1937, Yagoda was arrested on Stalin's orders. Yezhov announced Yagoda's arrest for diamond smuggling, corruption, and working as a German agent since joining the party in 1917. Yezhov even blamed Yagoda of an attempt to assassinate him by sprinkling [[mercury (element)|mercury]] around his office. He was accused of poisoning [[Maxim Gorky]] and his son. It was discovered that Yagoda's two Moscow apartments and his [[dacha]] contained 3,904 [[Pornography|pornographic]] photos, 11 pornographic films, 165 pornographically carved pipes, one [[dildo]], and the two bullets that killed Zinoviev and Kamenev.{{sfn|Montefiore|2007|p=195}} Yezhov took over the apartments. He had spent four million [[ruble]]s decorating his three homes, boasting that his garden had "2,000 orchids and roses."{{sfn|Montefiore|2007|p=85}} Yagoda was found guilty of [[treason]] and [[Conspiracy (political)|conspiracy]] against the Soviet government at the [[Case of the Anti-Soviet "Bloc of Rightists and Trotskyites"|Trial of the Twenty-One]] in March 1938. He denied he was a spy, but admitted most other charges.{{cite book|title=Report of Court Proceedings in the Case of the Anti-Soviet 'Bloc of Rights and Trotskyites'|publisher=People's Commissariat of Justice of the USSR|year=1938|location=Moscow|pages=573}} [[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn|Solzhenitsyn]] describes Yagoda as expecting [[clemency]] from Stalin after the show trial: "Just as though Stalin had been sitting right there in the hall, Yagoda confidently and insistently begged him directly for mercy: 'I appeal to you! ''For you'' I built two great canals!'". See Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn. ''The Gulag Archipelago'' Vol I–II, Harper & Row, 1973, {{ISBN|0-06-013914-5}} {{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1973/12/30/archives/solzhenitsyn-on-purge-trials-of-the-30s-the-gulag-archipelago.html|title=‘The Gulag Archipelago, 1918–1956’ Solzhenitsyn on Purge Trials of the 30's|first=Aleksandr I.|last=Solzhenitsyn|date=30 December 1973|publisher=|accessdate=1 April 2018|via=NYTimes.com}} Yagoda was summarily shot soon after the trial.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsru.com/russia/24jun2010/beria.html|title=Лаврентия Берию в 1953 году расстрелял лично советский маршал|publisher=|accessdate=1 April 2018}} His wife Ida Averbakh was executed in 1938. His sister, Lilya, was arrested on 7 May 1937, and shot on 16 July.{{cite book|last1=The final photograph of Lilya Genrikh, taken before her execution is in King|first1=David|title=Ordinary Citizens, the Victims of Stalin|date=2003|publisher=Francis Boutle|location=London|isbn=1 903427 150|page=142}} His brother-in-law, [[Leopold Averbakh]], was shot in August. In 1988, on the 50th anniversary of the trial, the Soviet authorities belatedly cleared all of the other 20 defendants of any criminal offence, admitting that the entire trial was built on false confessions. Yagoda was the only defendant not to be posthumously rehabilitated. ==Honours and awards== * [[File:Order of Lenin ribbon bar.png|25px]] [[Order of Lenin]] * [[File:Order of Red Banner ribbon bar.png|25px]] [[Order of the Red Banner]], twice (1927, 1930) * [[File:Orderredbannerlabor rib.png|25px]] [[Order of the Red Banner of Labour]] of the [[RSFSR]] (1932) ==Notes== {{commons category|Genrikh Yagoda}} {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book|ref=harv|last=Kotkin|first=Stephen|authorlink=Stephen Kotkin|title=Stalin: Volume I: Paradoxes of Power, 1878-1928|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OB90AwAAQBAJ|year=2014|publisher=Penguin Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-698-17010-0}} *{{cite book|ref=harv|last=Montefiore|first=Simon Sebag|authorlink=Simon Sebag Montefiore|title=Stalin: The Court of the Red Tsar|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f-HerzgvxssC|year=2007|publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-307-42793-9}} * Rayfield, Donald: ''Stalin und seine Henker.'' 2004 * Runes, Dagobert D.: ''Despotism, a pictorial history of tyranny.'' Philosophical Library 1963 * Н. В. Петров, К. В. Скоркин (N. W. Petrow, K.W. Skorkin): ''Кто руководил НКВД, 1934–1941 – Справочник.'' (Wer hatte die Regie im NKWD, 1934 bis 1941 – Verzeichnis); Swenja-Verlag 1999, {{ISBN|5-7870-0032-3}} [http://www.memo.ru/history/nkvd/kto/biogr/index.htm online] * А.Л. Литвин (A. L. Litwin): ''От анархо-коммунизма к ГУЛАГу: к биографии Генриха Ягоды'' (Über den Anarchokommunismus im Gulag: Mit einer Biografie von Genrich Jagoda) in ''1917 год в судьбах России и мира. Октябрьская революция.'' (Das Jahr 1917 und die Schicksale Russlands und der Welt) S. 299–314, Institut für russische Geschichte РАН, Moskau 1998, {{ISBN|5805500078}}. ==External links== * {{PM20|FID=pe/008657}} {{Marshals of the Soviet Union}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yagoda, Genrikh}} [[Category:1891 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:People from Rybinsk]] [[Category:People from Yaroslavl Governorate]] [[Category:Russian Jews]] [[Category:Old Bolsheviks]] [[Category:Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union members]] [[Category:People's Commissars and Ministers of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Commissars General of State Security]] [[Category:Great Purge perpetrators]] [[Category:Great Purge victims from Russia]] [[Category:Jewish people executed by the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Jewish socialists]] [[Category:Executed people from Yaroslavl Oblast]] [[Category:People executed for treason against the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Trial of the Twenty-One]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Red Banner]] [[Category:People of the 1905 Russian Revolution]]

[[Image:OLMO HAROLD 1978.jpg|right|thumb|270px|Dr Harold Olmo]] Dr. '''Harold Olmo''' (July 31, 1909 – June 30, 2006) was a pioneering [[viticulture|viticulturist]] and professor at the [[University of California, Davis]] where he created many new grape varieties known today as [[Olmo grapes]]. In the 1950s, he helped to establish California's first [[quarantine]] facility on the UC Davis campus to permit California growers to import foreign vines. This led to an expansion of California's [[wine]] industry as more ''[[Vitis vinifera]]'' was introduced to the area.
==Career== In 1955, Professor of [[Viticulture]] at the [[University of California]] Harold Olmo was in Western Australia studying climatic limitations of viticulture in the [[Swan Valley (Western Australia)|Swan Valley]]. Olmo spent eight months in Western Australia at the invitation of the Western Australian Vine Fruits Research Trust.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://winebookcellar.com.au/viticulture-environment/|title=Viticulture and Environment|last=Gladstones|first=John|publisher=Trivinum Press|year=2016|isbn=978-0-9945016-1-5|edition=Revised|location=Tanunda, South Australia|pages=ix}}</ref> When he published his report in 1956, one of the recommendations put forward was that [[Mount Barker, Western Australia|Mount Barker]] and the [[Frankland, Western Australia|Frankland]] of the [[Great Southern (wine region)|Great Southern]] area of [[Western Australia]] showed great promise for making table wines in the light traditional European style.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.albanygateway.com.au/what-to-do/great-southern-wine-region.html|work=Great Southern Wine Region History|title=The Great Southern wine region history|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
Olmo also developed more than 30 new grape varieties, including [[Ruby Cabernet]], [[Carnelian (grape)|Carnelian]], [[Rubired]] and [[Royalty (grape)|Royalty]].<ref name=" grape variety creation ">{{cite book|title= The encyclopedia of fruit & nuts |publisher= CABI International|year=2008|ISBN= 978-0-85199-638-7|author= J Janick, James Troop Professor in Horticulture, Purdue University, USA, R E Paull, Department Chair, Professor of Horticulture, University of Hawaii at Manoa, USA |page= 918}}</ref><ref name="VIVC">[[Vitis International Variety Catalogue]] (VIVC) ''[http://www.vivc.de/datasheet/dataResult.php?data=10288 Royalty] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160417040200/http://www.vivc.de/datasheet/dataResult.php?data=10288 |date=2016-04-17 }}'' Accessed: August 17th, 2012</ref><ref name="wine grapes">J. Robinson ''Jancis Robinson's Guide to Wine Grapes'' pg 161 Oxford University Press 1996 {{ISBN|0198600984}}</ref>
==See also== * [[California wine]] * [[Margaret River (wine region)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.lib.ucdavis.edu/dept/specol/collections/manuscripts/index.php?collection=242 Harold Olmo Papers] at [http://www.lib.ucdavis.edu/dept/specol/ Special Collections Dept.], University Library, University of California, Davis
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox person |name = James Carville |image = James Carville 1.jpg |birth_name = Chester James Carville Jr. |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1944|10|25}} |birth_place = [[Carville, Louisiana]], U.S. |residence = [[New Orleans]], Louisiana, U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |spouse = {{marriage|[[Mary Matalin]]|November 25, 1993}} |children=2 |alma_mater = [[Louisiana State University]]
(BA, JD) |website = {{url|carville.info|Official website}} }} '''Chester James Carville Jr.''' (born October 25, 1944) is an American [[political commentator]] and [[media personality]] who is a prominent figure in the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]. Carville gained national attention for his work as the lead strategist of the successful [[Bill Clinton presidential campaign, 1992|presidential campaign]] of then-[[Arkansas]] governor [[Bill Clinton]].{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2011/dec/05/david-axelrod/david-axelrod-calls-newt-gingrich-godfather-gridlo/ |title=David Axelrod calls Newt Gingrich 'the godfather of gridlock' |publisher=PolitiFact |accessdate=2012-09-05}} Carville also worked as a co-host of [[CNN]]'s ''[[Crossfire (U.S. TV program)|Crossfire]]''. After Crossfire, he appeared on CNN's news program ''[[The Situation Room with Wolf Blitzer|The Situation Room]]''. As of 2009, he hosts a weekly program on [[XM Radio]] titled ''60/20 Sports'' with [[Luke Russert]], son of [[Tim Russert]] who hosted NBC's ''[[Meet The Press]]''. He is married to [[US Libertarian Party|Libertarian]] political consultant [[Mary Matalin]]. In 2009, he began teaching political science at [[Tulane University]].{{cite web |last=Hobgood |first=Kathryn |title=Political Pundit Joins Faculty |publisher=[[Tulane University]] |date=2008-11-18 |location=New Orleans, LA |url=http://tulane.edu/news/newwave/111808_carville.cfm |accessdate=2009-01-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607105726/http://tulane.edu/news/newwave/111808_carville.cfm |archivedate=2010-06-07 |df= }} In 2014, Carville joined [[Fox News Channel]] as a contributor.{{cite web|title=James Carville joining Fox News as contributor |publisher=FOX News Network, LLC |date=2014-02-06 |location=New York, NY |url= http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2014/02/06/james-carville-joining-fox-news-as-contributor/ |accessdate=2014-06-14}} ==Early life and career== Carville, the oldest of eight children, was born on October 25, 1944, in [[Carville, Louisiana|Carville]], [[Louisiana]],{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/CNN/anchors_reporters/carville.james.html | title=CNN TV – Anchors/Reporters:James Carville}} the son of Lucille ([[married and maiden names|née]] Normand), a former school teacher who sold ''[[World Book Encyclopedia]]'' door-to-door, and Chester James Carville, a [[postmaster]] as well as owner of a [[general store]].[http://www.salon.com/columnists/jcarville.html The Columnists] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060128021024/http://www.salon.com/columnists/jcarville.html |date=2006-01-28 }}. Salon.{{cite news|title=James Carville has returned to Louisiana, living and teaching in New Orleans|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=AD&p_theme=ad&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=128474FE5EED2510&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D|publisher=News Library|date=May 17, 2009 |accessdate=5 September 2012}} The town of Carville was named after his paternal grandfather, Louis Arthur Carville, the postmaster.{{cite book|url={{Google books|F7Sb0j47Zl0C|page=PA30|keywords=|text=%22Louis Arthur Carville"|plainurl=yes}} |title=Carville: Remembering Leprosy In America – Marcia G. Gaudet – Google Books |via=[[Google Books]]|accessdate=2012-09-05}} Carville attended [[Ascension Catholic High School]] in [[Donaldsonville, Louisiana|Donaldsonville]], [[Louisiana]].{{cite conference |last1=Carville |first1=James |last2=[[Mary Matalin]] |title=CEA Washington Forum |publisher=[[Consumer Electronics Association]] |date=2007-03-27 |location=Washington, D.C. |url=http://www.ce.org/Events/event_info/downloads/WF07/3.27.07%20Carville%20&%20Matalin%20Keynote.doc |format=[[DOC (computing)|.doc]] |accessdate=2008-04-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080229191950/http://www.ce.org/Events/event_info/downloads/WF07/3.27.07%20Carville%20%26%20Matalin%20Keynote.doc |archivedate=2008-02-29 |df= }} Louis Arthur's mother, Octavia Dehon was of [[Belgians|Belgian]] parentage and had married John Madison Carville, described in a biography as "[[Irish people|Irish]]-born" and a "carpetbagger",http://www.mylouisianafamily.com/histories/Carville,%20Louis%20Arthur%20short%20biography.pdf both of whom established the general store operated by the family in Carville in 1882. He was born in Ireland in 1847 and his father, Alexander Carville, in 1810.{{cite web|url=http://www.genealogy.com/forum/surnames/topics/carville/66/|title=Descendants of Alexander Carvi - Genealogy.com|publisher=|accessdate=24 January 2017}} He received his [[undergraduate]] and [[Juris Doctor]] degrees from [[Louisiana State University]] (LSU). Carville is a member of the [[Sigma Nu]] fraternity.{{cite book|title=Gumbo|year=1963|publisher=Louisiana State University|location=Baton Rouge, LA|pages=236–7}} Carville spent two years serving in the [[United States Marine Corps]], achieving the rank of [[Corporal]],{{cite web|url=http://www.usni.org/news-and-features/10-people-you-didnt-know-were-us-marines |title=10 People You Didn't Know Were U.S. Marines | U.S. Naval Institute |publisher=Usni.org |accessdate=2012-09-05}}{{Cite news|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2010/06/02/carville-bumps-into-bp-ceo/?fbid=WmcDFSCWNDE#more-106834 |title=CNN Political Ticker: All politics, all the time Blog Archive - Carville bumps into BP CEO " - Blogs from CNN.com |publisher=Politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com |date=2010-06-02 |accessdate=2010-07-04}} and later worked as a high school teacher. Before entering politics, Carville worked as a [[litigator]] at a [[Baton Rouge]] law firm from 1973 to 1979. ==Political career== ===Early political career=== Carville was trained in consulting by [[Gus Weill]], who in 1958 had opened the first advertising firm which specialized in political campaigns in the state capital in Baton Rouge.{{cite web|url=http://www.lpb.org/programs/legends/weill.html|title=About Gus Weill|publisher=lpb.org|accessdate=August 21, 2012}} Prior to the Clinton campaign, Carville and consulting partner [[Paul Begala]] gained other well-known political victories, including the [[gubernatorial]] triumphs of [[Robert P. Casey|Robert Casey]] of [[Pennsylvania]] in 1986, and [[Zell Miller]] of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] in 1990, and [[Brereton Jones]] of [[Kentucky]] in 1991. But it was in 1991 when Carville and Begala rose to national attention, leading appointed incumbent [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Harris Wofford]] of Pennsylvania back from a 40-point poll deficit over [[White House]] hand-picked candidate [[Dick Thornburgh]]. It was during Wofford's campaign that the "[[it's the economy, stupid]]" strategy used by [[Bill Clinton]] in 1992 was first implemented. ===Bill Clinton's 1992 presidential campaign=== In 1992, Carville helped lead Bill Clinton to a win against [[George H. W. Bush]] in the presidential election. In 1993, Carville was honored as Campaign District Manager of the Year by the [[American Association of Political Consultants]]. His role in the Clinton campaign was documented in the feature-length Academy Award-nominated film ''[[The War Room]]''. One of the formulations he used in that campaign has entered common usage, derived from a list he posted in the war room to help focus himself and his staff, with these three points: # Change vs. more of the same. #[[It's the economy, stupid|The economy, stupid]]. # Don't forget health care.THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats – Clinton and Bush Compete to Be Champion of Change; Democrat Fights Perceptions of Bush Gain; Oct. 31, 1992, New York Times [https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/31/us/1992-campaign-democrats-clinton-bush-compete-be-champion-change-democrat-fights.html] ===Political and media work=== After 1992 Carville stopped working on domestic campaigns, stating that he would bring unneeded publicity. He then worked on a number of foreign campaigns, including those of [[Tony Blair]] – then Prime Minister of the [[United Kingdom]] – during the [[United Kingdom general election, 2001|2001 general election]]; [[Ehud Barak]] of [[Israel]]'s [[Israeli Labor Party|Labor Party]] (at the suggestion of Clinton, who had grown frustrated with [[Benjamin Netanyahu]]'s intransigence in the peace process) in the [[Israeli legislative election, 1999|1999 Knesset election]]; and the [[Liberal Party of Canada]]. In 2002, Carville helped Bolivian [[Gonzalo Sánchez de Lozada]] win the presidency in [[Bolivia]], while working as a Greenberg Carville Shrum (GCS) strategist. This was portrayed in the documentary ''[[Our Brand Is Crisis (2005 film)|Our Brand Is Crisis]]''. In 2004, he was brought in for last-minute consulting on [[John Kerry presidential campaign, 2004|John Kerry's presidential campaign]], but he did not play a major role. In 2005, Carville taught a semester of the course "Topics in American Politics" at [[Northern Virginia Community College]]. Among the guests he had come speak to the class were [[Al Hunt]], [[Mark Halperin]], Senator [[George Allen (U.S. politician)|George Allen]], [[George Stephanopoulos]], [[Karl Strubel]], [[Stan Greenberg]], [[Tony Blankley]], representatives from the [[Motion Picture Association of America]], and [[James Fallows]]. In 2006, Carville switched gears from politics to sports and became a host on a sports show called ''60/20 Sports'' on [[XM Satellite Radio]] with [[Luke Russert]], son of NBC journalist [[Tim Russert]]. The show is an in-depth look at the culture of sports based on the ages of the two hosts (60 and 20). After the Democrats' victory in the 2006 midterm election, Carville criticized [[Howard Dean]] as [[Democratic National Committee]] Chair, calling for his ouster, as he believed Dean had not spent enough money. In late November 2006, Carville proposed a truce of sorts.[http://hotlineblog.nationaljournal.com/archives/2006/11/carvilles_truce.html Hotline On Call: Carville's Truce?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061228161832/http://hotlineblog.nationaljournal.com/archives/2006/11/carvilles_truce.html |date=2006-12-28 }} ''The Hotline''. National Journal Group. 2006-11-30. Carville was the [[executive producer]] of the 2006 film ''[[All the King's Men (2006 film)|All the King's Men]]'', starring [[Sean Penn]] and [[Anthony Hopkins]], which is loosely based on the life of [[Louisiana]] [[Governor]] [[Huey Long]]. Carville had believed that [[Al Gore]], whom he helped put in the White House as vice president in 1992, would run for president in 2008.[https://archive.is/20120906215956/http://www.newsmax.com/archives/ic/2007/2/27/120317.shtml James Carville: Al Gore Will Run in 2008]. ''NewsMax.com''. 2007-02-27. This prediction did not come true. On March 4, 2009, ''[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]]'' reported that Carville, Paul Begala, and [[Rahm Emanuel]] were the architects of the Democratic Party's strategy to cast conservative [[talk radio]] host [[Rush Limbaugh]] as the face of the [[Republican Party (US)|Republican Party]].{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0309/19596.html|title=Rush Job: Inside Dems' Limbaugh Plan|last=Martin|first=Jonathan|date=March 4, 2009|publisher=Politico|accessdate=2009-03-12}} Carville was particularly critical of Limbaugh for saying he wanted [[Barack Obama]] to "fail". Afghan presidential candidate [[Ashraf Ghani]] hired Carville as a campaign advisor in July 2009. Carville said that the [[Afghan presidential election, 2009|2009 Afghan presidential election]] is "probably the most important election held in the world in a long time," and he called his new job "probably the most interesting project I have ever worked in my life."{{Cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/659/story/1312800.html|title=U.S. strategist helps rival of Afghan president|agency=Associated Press|date=2009-07-08|accessdate=2009-07-14}}{{Dead link|date=September 2010 |bot=H3llBot }} ''Cf.'' {{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601070&sid=aHvyg97ihhPM|title=Carville to Advise Karzai Challenger in Afghan Election Contest|publisher=Bloomberg|date=2009-07-06|accessdate=2009-07-14}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Carville, who works for Ghani ''pro bono'', when asked about similarities between politics in Afghanistan and politics in Louisiana, responded: "Yeah, I felt a little bit at home, to be honest with you."Bruce Eggler & Michelle Krupa, [http://nola.live.advance.net/news/t-p/neworleans/index.ssf?/base/news-11/1249104648283580.xml&coll=1&thispage=2 "Carville finds familiar politics in Afghanistan" (section titled "Going native")]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} in ''Times-Picayune'', 2009 August 1, Saint Tammany Edition, p. B3. In 2010, Carville worked as senior advisor for the campaign of Colombian presidential candidate [[Juan Manuel Santos]].[http://www.lasillavacia.com/historia/6941 "Juan Manuel Santos' campaign is running at full speed, La Silla Vacía (Colombian Political Website in Spanish)"]. He is acting as advisor for [[Daniel Scioli]] ([[Governor of Buenos Aires]]) re-election campaign. He is a regular contributor with [[Stan Greenberg]] to the weekly Carville-Greenberg Memo at [[The National Memo]]. ===Hillary Clinton's 2008 presidential primary campaign=== As an advisor to [[Hillary Clinton]]'s [[Hillary Rodham Clinton presidential campaign, 2008|2008 presidential campaign]], Carville told ''[[The New York Times]]'' on March 22, 2008, that New Mexico Governor [[Bill Richardson]], who had just endorsed Senator [[Barack Obama]] for the Democratic nomination, was comparable to [[Judas Iscariot]]. It was "an act of betrayal," said Carville. "Mr. Richardson's endorsement came right around the anniversary of the day when Judas sold out for [[30 pieces of silver]], so I think the timing is appropriate, if ironic," Mr. Carville said, referring to Holy Week. Governor Richardson had served in President Bill Clinton's administration as both [[United States Ambassador to the United Nations]] and [[United States Secretary of Energy|Secretary of Energy]], and Carville believed that Richardson owed an endorsement to Senator Clinton in exchange for being offered those posts by her husband. Carville also claimed that Richardson assured many in the Clinton campaign that he would at least remain neutral and abstain from taking sides.Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny, [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/22/us/politics/22richardson.html "First a Tense Talk With Clinton, Then Richardson Backs Obama"], ''The New York Times'', March 22, 2008. Richardson denied Carville's account, arguing that he had not made any promises to remain neutral. Richardson claims that his decision to endorse Obama was "clinched" by his speech on race relations following the swirl of controversy surrounding Obama's former pastor [[Jeremiah Wright]].{{Cite news| url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2008/03/22/richardson-obamas-speech-was-decisive/ | work=CNN | title=Richardson: Obama's speech was decisive | accessdate=2010-05-05 | date=2008-03-22}} Carville went on to note,"I doubt if Governor Richardson and I will be terribly close in the future," Carville said,{{Cite news|last=Sinderbrand |first=Rebecca |title=Carville: Controversial Judas comment 'had the desired effect' |work=CNN Political Ticker |publisher=CNNPolitics.com |date=2008-03-25 |url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2008/03/25/carville-controversial-judas-comment-had-the-desired-effect |accessdate=2008-04-01}} but "I've had my say...I got one in the [[List of baseball jargon (W)#wheelhouse|wheelhouse]] and I tagged it." Even as Clinton's campaign began to lose steam, Carville remained both loyal and positive in his public positions, rarely veering off message and stoutly defending the candidate. But on May 13, 2008, a few hours before the primary in [[West Virginia]], Carville remarked to an audience at [[Furman University]] in [[South Carolina]], "I'm for Senator Clinton, but I think the great likelihood is that Obama will be the nominee."{{Cite news| url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2008/05/13/carville-obama-likely-to-win-nomination/ | work=CNN | title=Carville: Obama likely to win nomination | accessdate=2010-05-05 | date=2008-05-13}} The moment marked a shift from his previous and often determinedly optimistic comments about the state of Clinton's campaign. After Barack Obama's clear lead for victory in the Democratic presidential campaign on June 3, James Carville said he was ready to open up his wallet to help Obama build a political war chest to take on [[John McCain]] in November.{{cite web|url=http://www.nndb.com/org/684/000167183/ |title=Obama for America |publisher=Nndb.com |accessdate=2010-07-04}} ==Personal life== Carville is married to [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]-turned-[[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] political consultant [[Mary Matalin]], who worked for [[George H. W. Bush]] on his 1992 presidential reelection campaign. Carville and Matalin were married in New Orleans in October 1993. They have two daughters: Matalin Mary "Matty" Carville and Emerson Normand "Emma" Carville. In 2008, Carville and Matalin relocated their family from Virginia to New Orleans.{{Cite news|last=Argetsinger |first=Amy |authorlink=Amy Argetsinger |author2=[[Roxanne Roberts]] |title=His Family Is Following the Ragin' Cajun Home |work=The Reliable Source |pages=C03 |publisher=The Washington Post |date=2008-03-27 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/03/27/AR2008032700006.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012190812/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/03/27/AR2008032700006.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-10-12 |accessdate=2008-04-01}} Carville joined the faculty of Louisiana State University's Manship School of Mass Communication in January 2017. ==Bibliography== '''Politics''' *''All's Fair: Love, War and Running for President'' (1995), with Mary Matalin and [[Peter Knobler]] *''We're Right, They're Wrong: A Handbook for Spirited Progressives'' (1996) *''...And The Horse He Rode In On: The People vs. [[Kenneth Starr]]'' (1998) *''Stickin: The Case for Loyalty'' (2000) with [[Paul Begala]] *''Suck Up, Buck Up... and Come Back When You Foul Up'' (2001) *''Had Enough?'' (2004) * ''Take It Back: Our Party, Our Country, Our Future'' (2006) with Paul Begala *''40 More Years: How the Democrats Will Rule the Next Generation'' (2009) *''It's the Middle Class, Stupid!'' (2012) with [[Stan Greenberg]] * ''Love & War: Twenty Years, Three Presidents, Two Daughters and One Louisiana Home'', (2014) with [[Mary Matalin]] * ''We're Still Right, They're Still Wrong: The Democrats' Case for 2016'', (2016) '''Children's Fiction''' *''Lu and the Swamp Ghost'' (2004) with co-author [[Patricia McKissack]] and illustrator [[David Catrow]] ==Film and television appearances== [[File:Carville-Ellison-2007.jpg|thumb|Carville and [[Keith Ellison (politician)|Keith Ellison]] in 2007]] *Carville takes a lead role in ''[[The War Room]]'', a documentary about [[Bill Clinton]]'s 1992 presidential campaign, together with [[George Stephanopoulos]]. *He appeared in the 1996 film ''[[The People vs. Larry Flynt]]'' as attorney [[Simon Leis]].{{cite web|title=The People vs. Larry Flynt (1996)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117318/|publisher=International Movie Database (IMDb)|accessdate=5 September 2012}} *He appeared in three episodes of the sitcom ''[[Mad About You]]'' playing himself, as head of a political consulting firm that hires Jamie Buchman, played by [[Helen Hunt]]. *He has a guest role on the sitcom ''[[Spin City]]'', where he is interviewed for a job as campaign manager. *Carville reportedly accepted the role of Crazy Ray in the cancelled animated [[Walt Disney Animation Studios]] film ''My Peoples'', which was later re-titled ''A Few Good Ghosts''.{{cite web|url=http://animatedviews.com/2012/director-barry-cook-remembers-the-peoples-of-walt-disney-feature-animation-florida/|title=Director Barry Cook remembers the Peoples of Walt Disney Feature Animation Florida|website=Animated Views|last=Armstrong|first=Josh|date=July 30, 2012|access-date=January 24, 2018}} *In the films ''[[Old School (film)|Old School]]'' and ''[[Wedding Crashers]]'', Carville makes cameo appearances as himself. *He appeared as himself in ''[[Our Brand Is Crisis (2005 film)|Our Brand Is Crisis]]'', a documentary about the Bolivian presidential election. *Carville appears as the [[Governor]] of [[Missouri]], [[Thomas Theodore Crittenden|Thomas Crittenden]], in the 2007 movie ''[[The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford]]''. *He appeared as himself in [[NBC]]'s comedy ''[[30 Rock]]'', season 2 episode 8 "[[Secrets and Lies (30 Rock)|Secrets and Lies]]". *He appeared in cartoon form in the ''[[Family Guy]]'' episode "[[Running Mates (Family Guy)|Running Mates]]." *He starred in [[Steven Soderbergh]]'s [[HBO]] series ''[[K Street (TV series)|K Street]]'' along with his wife. *Carville is a regular guest on ''[[The Tony Kornheiser Show]]'' where he picks both NFL and college football games against the ''[[USA Today]]'' spreads. *He voiced Judge Roland McFarlane in the ''[[King of the Hill]]'' episode "Jumpin' Crack Bass". *He made a cameo appearance in ''[[The Muppets (film)|The Muppets]]. *He made a notable appearance on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' to condemn Barack Obama's response to the oil spill where he claimed that 'We're About to Die Down Here!'{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lO1lO1CVkTE |title=James Carville Slams Obama on Oil Spill: 'We're About to Die Down Here!' Stephanopoulos spins |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=2012-09-05}} *Beginning in 2012, Carville and Matalin appeared in "Cocktail Party" commercials for [[Maker's Mark]] Kentucky Straight Bourbon. *Carville appears as himself in the film ''[[G.I. Joe: Retaliation]]'', introducing the President at a fundraising event. *He was portrayed on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', mostly by [[Bill Hader]].{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/news/snl-james-carville/|title=Snl James Carville|publisher=|accessdate=24 January 2017}} *He and his wife perform the epilogue to [[Hayes Carll]]'s political comedy song "Another Like You".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YCnt-drXsiU|title=Hayes Carll - Another Like You ft. Cary Ann Hearst|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=2015-04-27}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} http://www.lsu.edu/mediacenter/news/2017/09/26carville.eb.php ==Further reading== *Clinton, Bill (2004). ''[[A Soldier, A Senator, A Serious Sin: An Epic Louisiana Election|Long Shot]]''. {{ISBN|9780-692-79533-0}}. ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Wikiquote}} * {{Official website}} * {{IMDb name|142598}} * {{Fox News personalities}} {{CNN Anchors}} {{Louisiana Political Museum and Hall of Fame}} {{Portal bar|Biography|Politics|Television in the United States}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carville, James}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:American campaign managers]] [[Category:American people of Belgian descent]] [[Category:American political consultants]] [[Category:American political commentators]] [[Category:American political writers]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:American schoolteachers]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Cajun people]] [[Category:Clinton administration personnel]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Louisiana Democrats]] [[Category:Louisiana lawyers]] [[Category:Louisiana State University alumni]] [[Category:Louisiana State University Law Center alumni]] [[Category:People from Iberville Parish, Louisiana]] [[Category:Tulane University faculty]] [[Category:United States Marines]] [[Category:United States presidential advisors]] [[Category:Writers from New Orleans]] [[Category:Catholics from Louisiana]]
